posts.body:
>>d7e8c991-bada-4459-865f-1b1edeb12d86
The problem is post numbers are client side. So if your client retrieves some more posts it didn't have between the moment that you click on a post number and the moment you click "reply", the post that shows up as you replying to won't be the correct one.
You can (mostly) prevent this by visually checking the post number is still the right one when you click on "reply".

>>b584c54d-0d2c-4045-a977-2d1cb860ee97
Zites can ony execute javascript. No different than any clearnet site.
I'd get into nntpchan but there is too little documentation. For example, how do I run my own instance? How do I run it over Tor? With ZeroNet everybody is running their own instance by default and can easily enable Tor by editing a few config files.

>>c4a4e07c-2005-4960-93a1-bfce62e10fe5
Liking them (for themselves) and believing owning them should be an inalienable constitutional right that should never be violated are two different things.
Leftists inherently like central planning. That includes centralizing law enforcement, personal and national defense as well as the decision making with respect to who should own guns or not.
Show me one leftist organization with more than 10 members that is staunchly pro-gun. There is none.

>>ccd929dd-7749-44cc-ae70-868c41bfc1a5

Who? Cocksuckers United?

>>81468416-9ded-4946-bf1b-db9a8bb40aeb
Right, now prove
- That they're leftist
- That they supports gun ownership unconditionally
- That they have more than 10 people
>Also you're lying about leftists, inherently, liking centralization.
It's true though. Anarchists might not like centralization, but their ideology is so incoherent it doesn't matter.
>The whole point is to decentralize the work place as much as possible through democracy.
In theory, everybody owns the productive enterprises. In practice, direct democracy is impossible for more than one or two decisions a year. So you need indirect democracy, in which a select few end up taking every decision. So power is centralized in the government. You, as an everyday guy, only have the choice to pick between one bunch of crooks and another bunch of crooks once every X number of years.

>>550534f8-9703-4063-9973-6186e02b9e56
>In reality everyone should just be free to act autonomously with out the intervention of others.
>Why is you people can't just let people be free?
Nice LARP.

>>532340ef-bfb1-49dd-b331-e3c33186ac76
It was set up that way because the spambots were making the site unusable.

>>a775c7dc-07fb-4520-8177-e1b0f329ac2d
Security through obscurity is not worth it. People could hack their clients to display the IDs, or just dig through their client's files. Better to just let everyone be aware they're pseudonymous rather than anonymous.
The obfuscation is just picking a random string of characters as your username and changing it as often as you can be bothered to.
What could be done is making a script to generate IDs and switch to them automatically before each post, but it would require some serious programming work.

>>1e962974-0d23-4823-856d-73dd2d32fc31
You are LARPing as someone who wants freedom. The government monitoring all your transactions so they can come steal shit from you and give it to the nigger next door whenever you make a dime is not freedom.

>>ccc47e60-4f7e-4c0f-b641-b993b4dd864f
What is leftism if not stealing from the haves and give it to the have nots? (at least in theory)

>>5e0549bb-a291-4863-9040-9b94baac480d
>Look i'm trying to be nice, but, at least read what I posted prior to this:
I don't give a shit about you being nice.
>"the left" typically holds the view that workers should control the means of production democratically rather than autocratically like you all believe.
What if I spend all my free time making means of production? What if I spend my life working in exchange of [real goods] so I can exchange it for means of production? That's right, the commie gov will come and steal that from me. Or from my children. Or from my grandchildren. Whenever it becomes big enough for the gov to consider it worth stealing.
>It has nothing to do with "steal from the rich and giving to the poor" though that can always be fun to do!
1. Kill yourself.
2. You are contradicting your previous sentence. The way they would "democratically control them" would be by stealing them from their owner first.
>"The haves" as you so , bluntly, put it, subsist off the labor of the working classes, that is, the people who own the means of production subsist off no to little labor of their own while the people who actually produce commodities get ripped off.
They aren't being ripped off. Without the means of production the capitalist and their ancestors spent their lives working towards owning, the workers would produce even less than the portion they get from operating the means of production owned by the capitalist. If that was not the case, then they would just walk away and produce commodities at home rather than asking the capitalist to let them use his capital.
>Why the hell is that ok?
Because people should be able to decide who or what the fruits of their labor goes towards?

>>36eb24e8-a3ed-447b-b82a-f7a67a221cec
He can remove them from the software with a little bit of coding, but you can re-enable them just as easily by patching your own client-side copy of it.

>>51557b25-6c34-419c-b09e-946e0d8e5280
>Do you mind telling me exactly how you will go about creating these means of production?
1. Acquire the necessary parts
2. Put them together
3. Voila
>You realize that task is not possible to do on your own, correct?
Sometimes it is, sometimes it isn't. If you can't do it by yourself then pool your resources with other people who are trying to achieve the same thing you are.
>And even if it was; Why does that justify you having autocratic control over it?
We're getting into philosophy here. I don't know what's your preferred moral philosophy, but from an utilitarian perspective, it could be that letting people who are capable of creating things own what they create makes them more likely to survive than the people who aren't, thus advancing darwinian evolution, and making everybody happier in the future because of more resources being available as a result of the higher average intelligence levels.
>Ownership is not as elf justifying metric.
Depends on your moral philosophy. For deontologists it sure might be, and even for utilitarians under some conditions like the one I mentioned above.
Then there are the non-cognitivists, for whom "people should own what they make" does not mean anything other than "I would like this to be the case".
In any case I don't think we are going to solve the relevant millenarian ethical and meta-ethical questions today.
>Yes they are, because what they produce is worth twice as much as they are paid.
Those things are not created just by them. They are created by the combination of them plus the capital that was produced by somebody else. So it stands to reason that if they didn't create the stuff all by themselves, they don't get the money all by themselves either.
>You're just spouting off a bunch of bullshit that you cannot prove and which you have pulled directly out of your ass.
No.
>People cannot just "create" things because the means by which to do so are owned privately (autocratically.)
>It's like mini feudalism.
It's not like there's any other way of doing things. If somebody is retarded enough that he can't make a deal with somebody else who has those means in exchange for a fraction of the results of the productive process, then he won't be smart enough to avoid getting swayed out of the fruits of his labor by the leaders of whatever movement he helped get into power (just like it happened anywhere there was a commie revolution ever).
>>813fb8ba-d752-4842-a481-2de36f42ded1
Well, to be fair pretty much every corner of the Earth is owned by someone already. So you pretty much need somebody's permission to even build a hut in the middle of the jungle, or the firepower to defend it when they come fuck your shit up. Heck, even if you build an island in the middle of the ocean you won't be left alone.

>>ff66e70c-cb8f-4bf5-84c5-82d28a5e8e7a
Why does it have to be one computer, all done by just one person? That's not the minimum requirement for "producing" something. Computers are not produced by single companies. Not even by single countries.
But a single person can produce the design for the mask aligner. Or he can produce a wafer with a grown gate oxide layer when given a wafer with the patterned photoresist, a kiln, a spin coater and a bunch of chemicals. Bam, you just created the (consumable) means of production for producing wafers with the interconnect layer finished.

>>fb4a8ac1-1caf-4d87-b0e4-b76092ac22e4
Prove to me you're morally justified to steal from somebody else even if your life sucks.
Pro tip: **you can't.**

>not possible on your own.
For you, maybe. I've produced things that way and all I've started with was a $200 laptop and a room in my mom's house.
>Generally it is not.
Generally as in "generally for most people" or "generally for most things"?
>Yeah but you didn't actually create anything. You just employed other people to do it for you.
Nope. I didn't employ anyone. I created software by myself and sold it to other people.
>I am a moral nihilist/egoist.
Then the notions of right and wrong don't exist for you. By your own philosophy there's nothing wrong with capitalism.
>Let's look at it like this; if you abstract away everything but the relationship of person A and person B;
>If person A employs a person (person B) to create X for him then obviously the what Person B recivies for his labor must be equivalent to X otherwise person B would not work for person A because that's how exchanges work.
<Let's look at it like this; if you ignore the inconvenient parts of my argument and oversimplify the situation, then ...
Heh. Nice try though.
>Not currently, what do you think this conversation is about?
Not currently and not in the future. The conversation is about educating you btw.

>>26b0ace1-da80-44bb-8fb3-bb01790a1bee

>>ad67ece4-a0b0-46ca-acc5-e56649faaab1
>fucking kek.
Out of arguments?
>Generally as in 99% of the time; unless you are making autistic mud pies or some shit.
Then I guess I'm part of the 1%?
>I assume you built the computer you use too?
No? I said "acquire the parts", not "build the parts". Doing labor for somebody else or asking for charity is a valid way of acquiring parts.
>This is true. There is only my self interest and the destruction of the capitalist mode of production is aligned with that.
Lol. So not even commies believe in communism now? Good to know.
>Wow not an argument.
Neither was yours sweetie.
>Lmfao, imagine thinking i';m the one being educated.=
Lets leave it up to the audience to decide.

>>3c491ee8-c4d9-4c7f-b172-f5f48a57cb5e
That's not what you claimed. You claimed "the labor of many should not be owned by the labor of few". So presumably your implicit claim was that the labor of many is owned by the labor of the few.

>>d5157421-c09c-446e-9442-4a4ad53feff8
In case you decide to push the contents of that zip, be aware it includes a read-only root content.json that you would need to avoid copying or delete in order to generate your own in the publishing process.

>>849f3612-725d-4162-b5e7-55be3cab0807
>If you own capital, yeah, probs
So everyone who owns a laptop is part of the 1%? Nice.
>The people who do not create the mills should not own the mills 
Define what you mean by "should". You yourself said morally there's nothing wrong with it, so in what sense there is anything wrong with it? Because you don't like it? That doesn't mean they "should not", that only means they should not if they want to please you.
>The people who actually build things of utility are the ones who should own them
Again, on what basis? Because you want it to be so doesn't mean they "should".
>not the people who just "own them" for no reason other than "cause I won them"
They don't own it "cause I won them", they own it because the own the means that were used to build them, which is a shorthand for saying "they have the military means of defending the usage of those goods for their preferred purposes, and under some moral systems (not including nihilism), they also should be the ones who determine the usage of those goods".
>those people have done no actual labor themselves; eg the production of useful commodities.
If those people had done no actual labor themselves, then they would not be in a position of militarily defending the usage of those goods. At the very least they did enough work to convince people to both work for them, and to work towards militarily defending the capital and it's output when combined with the work performed by the first group.
>This makes no sense, go back to reddit.
no u
>ok??? I mean we are on a board mostly consisting of radical right wingers, so.
What other alternative there is? If you don't like it you're free to go to [whatever leftypol's bunker was called].

>>9a0d2f1b-6fe1-41d1-badb-2afef3560e6f
"The labor of many should not be owned by the labor of few", "people own things" and "capital owns labor" are literally three different claims. Make up your mind on what claims you want to make.

>>fdf40b57-5861-4e1f-a245-4b06ba7ba63e
Yeah. You'd have to search and replace
[code]
"(src\\/)?.{40}(-thumb)?\\.(png|jpeg|jpg|gif|webm|mp4|ogg|mp3|pdf|epub)(\\.piecemap\\.msgpack)?"
[/code]
with something like
[code]
"(src\\/)?.{40}(-thumb)?\\.(png|jpeg|jpg|gif|webm|mp4|ogg|mp3|pdf|epub|zip|7z|rar)(\\.piecemap\\.msgpack)?"
[/code]
in users\content.json and then sign and publish.
